utterances: Unidentified Man #1: Probably a 40.
The last days of Israel's election campaign did not work out as Benjamin Netanyahu might have hoped.
The prime minister has warned his Likud Party it may lose in today's election.
The center-right Likud was trailing a center-left coalition in the final round of public opinion surveys.
It turns out Netanyahu's dramatic speech to the U.S.
Congress, a speech that challenged the Obama administration's engagement with Iran, gave him only a brief boost in polls, which was offset by some withering criticism at home.
NPR's Emily Harris is based in Jerusalem, and she's on the line with us for more.
And, Emily, that speech to the U.S.
Congress was supposed to gain Netanyahu an advantage, but it didn't quite happen that way.
That's right, Renee.
A lot of what he said in the speech on Iran wasn't news to people in Israel.
And what happened was people started questioning the tensions the speech had created with the U.S.
and asking, well, isn't the relationship with the U.S.
part of Israel's essential security?
The left wing - the central-left party led by Yitzak Herzog took advantage of this, and he said if he wins, he would make it a priority to re-establish a close relationship with Washington.
Well, another thing that's happened and just hours before the voting began, Netanyahu made what seemed like rather a stunning announcement.
He said that were he to become prime minister again, there would be no Palestinian state created.
What is that all about?
Is that aimed at getting votes?
Netanyahu was asked directly in an interview, if you are prime minister again, will there be a Palestinian state created on your watch?
And he began talking about how this is not the right time to give back land; it would create a launching pad for attacks on Israel.
And then the interviewer interrupted him and said, so if you are prime minister, there won't be a Palestinian state created?
And he said indeed.
So this is the furthest he's gone so far in actually saying he would not pursue a two-state solution.
It's a change from a 2009 speech where he said he was open to the idea under certain conditions.
He has been making these comments recently about this is not the time, there's chaos around Israel.
So in that sense, it reflected the direction he's been going to.
But he's definitely trying to get votes, especially get people further to the right wing then positions he's had to come back and vote for him and the Likud Party in this election.
Well, just lastly, despite his party's fallen opinion polls, Netanyahu could still keep this job, right?
That's right.
He could win, first of all.

And second of all, even if his Likud Party doesn't emerge with the most votes, he could be the one who could negotiate successfully among the 11 or 12 parties that are supposed to get in Parliament and build a coalition government out of that with him at the helm.
Emily, thinks very much.
Thanks, Renee.
NPR's Emily Harris speaking to us from Jerusalem.
New York Times correspondent Rukmini Callimachi has been analyzing the tradecraft of the terrorists who executed the attacks in Brussels and the November attacks in Paris, and she joins me now.
Welcome to the program once again.
Thank you for having me, Robert.
First, the Brussels attackers - what conclusions have you drawn, first, from that blurry photo of three people at the airport?
The first thing that we notice about these people from the photo is how calm they appear.
They're walking, you could say, almost casually, relaxed into the entryway of the airport.
You can imagine that they're just people setting off on a trip and not bombers that are about to blow themselves up.
This we've seen over and over again with these ISIS operatives.

During the November 13 attacks in the Comptoir Voltaire bistro in Paris, the witness statements stated that the bomber walked in, smiled, calmly looked around him, excused himself for the noise he had caused, and then pushed the detonator.
You've written in The New York Times about the use in the Paris explosions of a substance called TATP.
And, again, stories of that have been found in the searches in Brussels.
What's different or interesting about TATP?
TATP has very much become the signature explosive that ISIS's external operations branch seems to be using in Europe.
The reason that we're seeing it is TATP is made from two ingredients, acetone and hydrogen peroxide.
Hydrogen peroxide, that comes from hair bleach, and acetone is found in nail polish remover.
It's very, very hard for governments to put in trip wires that would alert them to the purchase of these ingredients.
These are ingredients that you can buy, you know, in a place like Home Depot or in a beauty supply shop and then return home and bake the bomb.
Before the Brussels attacks, you did reporting about how the Paris attackers had communicated among themselves.
As you tell it, they were extremely disciplined in keeping their communications secure.
How did they do that?
Abdelhamid Abaaoud, as you'll recall, was considered the architect of the Paris attacks.
When his body was found, they found near him literally dozens of disposable cell phones that were still inside their wrapper.
They hadn't even been used.
And at different sites where they carried out their killings, the same thing.
The police found burner phones - phones that had been activated hours, sometimes minutes before the attack.

From what we can tell, they only used these phones and then the phones that they took from their hostages inside the Bataclan in order to communicate with each other, with the police and as well as with accomplices that have not yet been caught.
This, to me, points to the evolution, the arc of ISIS's external operations arm.
Earlier, in 2014 and 2015, a number of plots were foiled, specifically because the fighters made really stupid errors.
For instance, Ibrahim Boudina, who was arrested in the city of Cannes, had voluminous Facebook chats with various friends of his, which allowed authorities to figure out what he was doing.

Given the practices of these people that you have reported about from France and what you've learned from Brussels, is ISIS or the people who are allied with ISIS, are they now ahead of law enforcement at this point?
Is there one of those moments were they just have the advantage?
That should lead to patients both feeling better on dialysis and having fewer complications that can lead to hospital stays, which should save money.
Medicare's goal is to implement the new payment system January 1.
For NPR News, I'm Eric Whitney.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Unidentified Man #2: Malt liquor.
Right now we return to London where the death toll from this morning's terrorist attacks on the public transit system stands at 37.
That's according to British police.
More than 700 are injured.
The blasts took place during rush hour on three crowded underground trains and a double-decker bus.
The attacks threw downtown London into confusion, filling the hospitals and sending doctors into the streets to treat the wounded.
They also disrupted the G8 meeting in Gleneagles, Scotland.
Prime Minister Tony Blair left that meeting to return to London.
He accused the attackers of trying to derail the meeting.
For most of this hour we talked about one of the main proposals the G8 must weigh in on this week, and a particular focus for Prime Minister Blair, a doubling of aid to Africa.
President Bush, who is also attending the conference, drew a direct contrast between the goals of the conference and the perpetrators of the attacks in London.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: You got people here who are working to alleviate poverty, to help rid the world of the pandemic of AIDS.
They're working on ways to have clean environment.
And on the other hand you got people killing innocent people.
The contrast couldn't be clearer between the intentions and the hearts of those of us who care deeply about human rights and human liberty and those who kill.
President George Bush speaking this morning at the G8 Summit in Scotland.
With us now on the phone from London is Adam Stacey.
He was on the train this morning that was attacked near the Kings Cross station in London.
He took a photo of the scene.
You can find that photo on our Web site, npr.org.
Adam is with us now.
Thanks so much for being with us, Adam, after what has to have been an extraordinarily difficult day for you.
Yeah, yeah.
Hard to imagine.
Maybe you can describe for us what happened on the train you were on this morning.

Yeah, well, I was just getting a train into work with my friends this morning, and it was particularly crowded, like it was the most crowded I've actually seen the tube for a long time, and we all kind of packed in there, and then it was between Kings Cross station and the next station, and it was actually in the middle of the tunnel when suddenly was a loud bang and the train suddenly jolted to a stop.
And obviously everyone was kind of panicking and screaming at this point.
I looked around and suddenly smoke from the next carriage started pouring into our carriage, and obviously you're gonna expect the worst when you see that.

Like at first I thought maybe it would be some sort of chemical attack, and just, like, covered my mouth as quickly as I could, and everyone else around was just like covering their mouths to make sure they--we weren't, like, breathing in the smoke.
So you did immediately perhaps--it sounds like you immediately thought that it was a terrorist attack.
Oh, yeah, first impression is, yeah, 'cause like everything is sort of happening in the media, like, past couple years.
But when something--anything that happens like that, the first thing that just triggered in your mind is, like, it's gotta be something serious.
How did you get out of the train?
Was there panic or was it orderly?
There was actually--luckily our carriage, it wasn't too bad.

A few people were crying and praying, and obviously there was a lot of stress there, but basically we waited for engineers to come and open the doors for us, which is after about half an hour, 45 minutes.

But in some of the other carriages we could hear people really kind of screaming and panicking, and they were smashing windows and climbing out and actually walking down the tracks like in the tunnel.
Oh, I imagine--I would guess that it would have to be extremely difficult to wait in a smoke-filled train car for 45 minutes.
...(Unintelligible).
I'm surprised people didn't panic more.
Oh, yeah.
I mean, was just very lucky.
I mean, look, me and my friend, we were trying to calm people down around us, and there were a few other people on the train who were just saying to everyone, `Listen, just like stay calm.
Just wait for someone to come and help us and, you know, the help will be here, like, soon to come and, like, get us all out.
And luckily it wasn't like a massive panic, because otherwise in that kind of crowded situation, people could have got trampled to death.
Now apparently you took a photo which has made its way around the world on Web sites, including our own, NPR's Web site.
Tell us about that picture and how that came about.

Well ...(unintelligible) at a time we didn't actually know there'd been a bomb explosion, so we were under the impression at the time it could have been some sort of electrical failure which had caused the train to stop.

So, I mean, obviously with the smoke we thought it was pretty serious, but then as we were getting out of the train I thought, `Well, let's just get a photo of this,' just so we can show our friends that, you know, this is what happened, and then it was only later when I got into work that I saw on the news about, you know, the other attacks that happened in London and the bombs had gone off at other train stations and on the buses, I suddenly realized, like, how serious this was, and then I decided to send that photo on to one of the newspapers.
Yeah.
Then about 10, 15 minutes, it was just everywhere, all over the press, all over like the main Web pages of the news companies.
Yeah.
Kind of surreal now.
So you--even as you left the station, you did not understand how many people had been injured and how many deaths were involved?
Right.
But...
You didn't see any victims or anything like that at that time?
